title: riverdip
author: riverdip
content: A group of influencers associated with the cryptocurrency exchange FTX are being sued in a class-action lawsuit worth $1 billion. The lawsuit alleges that these influencers promoted fraudulent cryptocurrency projects to their followers, causing them to suffer significant losses. The suit also alleges that FTX was complicit in these fraudulent activities, as they allowed the influencers to promote these projects on their platform. The defendants have not yet responded to the lawsuit.For full article: https://cryptobasket.org/posts/ftx-influencers-are-being-sued-in-a--1-billion-class-action-for-allegedly-promoting-crypto-fraud/

comments.author: StarKay
comments.body: I don't know why people don't want to take responsibility for their investment decisions, the so called influencers are people that have large followers on social media and sometimes celebrities but that doesn't make them financial advisers. Freedom of speech is guaranteed and I think I am free to talk about any project that I find interesting.I don't see the lawsuit going anywhere, they should rather direct their anger at FTX management team.

comments.body: As reported by some news sources, YouTube "influencers" have been sued for promoting FTX crypto fraud without disclosing compensation. comments.author: cryptomaniac_xxx
comments.body: It's two fold though, we as investors have the responsibilities to put our money whenever we want it to be regardless if someone will influence us or not. On the other hand, this influencers don't know if the project like FTX will be successful or not.So even if they are going to be sued, it might be difficult for the court to proved that they are involved with SBF or anyone from the FTX itself.Everyone here can shill for the project itself, in my opinion. But let's see how it goes.

comments.author: decodx
comments.body: I will never understand these types of lawsuits. What are they based on? I mean, FTX is a regulated exchange with all the necessary permits and licenses to operate. If anyone should be sued, it is the institutions that issued them those permits and were supposed to supervise their work.I'm not defending influencers here. They certainly have their flaws, but it's not reasonable to expect them to predict the future. How could they have known that it would turn out to be a scam? They were likely presented with a convincing pitch and believed that FTX was a legitimate investment opportunity, just like many others in the market.

comments.author: serjent05
comments.body: I think FTX is a special case wherein influencers shouldn't be blamed because FTX started out as a legit company.  They have their licenses and authorities even recognized them.  FTX leaders are even featured by different popular publishing companies.  So I don't think that influencers promoting FTX should be blamed for the lost of money of investors.But in case the company is an obvious scam, influencers who promoted it should be held accountable for the losses of people swayed to invest in that scam company.

comments.author: Asiska02
comments.body: If there are no proven facts that these influencers were aware that they were promoting a possible scam project or a susceptible scam project in the first place, they should not face any legal action for their lack of knowledge about the project. I believe that these influencers are only there to promote a project and be compensated for it; those who want to invest in those projects should do so at their own risk after conducting research on it. Part of the agreement between the two parties will be for the influencer to send a message to their followers encouraging them to invest in the project; however, they will have no choice but to follow the terms of the client/employer. Most people who are familiar with the cryptocurrency market are aware that influencers are just doing what they’re ask to do, they should always invest at their own risk.
